stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Norwegian Package Tracking Themed Phishing Email
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 5 February 2014 a U.S. government department reported observing phishing emails using Norwegian language and a postal or package tracking theme. The emails included a malicious attachment which installed a RAT / backdoor.
This product was originally published as US-CERT MIFR-344911.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: On 5 February 2014 a phishing email was observed targeting U.S. government employees using a spoofed email address purporting to be from the Norwegian postal service. The email used a package tracking theme containing the Norwegian subject line "Din sporing er tilgjengelig" [Your tracking is available] and the attachment PostenTracking.exe.

The file PostenTracking.exe is a malicious attachment to the email. If executed, the malware writes a copy of itself to: %USERPROFILE%\Application Data\server.exe and listens for C2 commands over TCP port 1158.
To maintain persistence, the Registry is modified to add server.exe to the "Run" key.

The malware is hard-coded to recieve commands from IP 37.187.48.49 uisng a TCP connection on port 1158. The malware is hard-coded to receive plain-text commands via the connection including the following:
MAININFO (obtain information from the infected host) serverinfo (report the server's configuration data) lfiles [dir] (list the files in a given directory] listwindows (list active windows on the infected host) closewindow [window ID] (close active window) changetitle [window ID|new text] (update title text for active window) newdir [dir] (create a new directory) deletedir [dir] (delete a directory) deletefile [file] (delete a file) serviceslist (list system services) startservice [service name] (start a service) stopservice [service name] (stop a service) removeservice [service name] (delete a service) processlist (list system processes) suspendprocess [PID] (suspend a process) resumeprocess [PID] (resume a suspended processs) endprocess [PID] (kill a process) modulelist (list DLLs loaded by the server) systeminfo (provided verbose system information, MAC address, privilege level of compromised account, CPU and memory info, etc.) uninstallserver (uninstall the RAT)
The malware may attempt to modify host based firewall rules to allow the C2 connection, for example:
netsh advfirewall firewall delete rule profile=any name=Win2y2 netsh advfirewall firewall add rule action=allow profile=any protocol=any enable=yes direction=out name=Win2y2 netsh advfirewall firewall add rule action=allow profile=any protocol=any enable=yes direction=in name=Win2y2 program=%USERPROFILE%\Application Data\server.exe

On installation of the malware, the file log.dat is created in the same directory as server.exe (MD5 aef99cc4bee92ba2a8c54bb942327888). No additional information about the file is currently available.
